title: Philoteris
text:
Philoteris was a village in <a href="ancient%20Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> located in the <a href="Faiyum%20Oasis">Faiyum Oasis</a>. It was founded by <a href="Pharaoh">Pharaoh</a> <a href="Ptolemy%20II%20Philadelphus">Ptolemy II Philadelphus</a> of the <a href="Ptolemaic%20Kingdom">Ptolemaic Kingdom</a>, who named it for his sister, <a href="Philotera">Philotera</a>. At the time of its founding, approximately 800 inhabitants were <a href="Ancient%20Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a>ians, while 400 were <a href="Ancient%20Greece">Ancient Greeks</a>.
In 2017, the first Egyptian–<a href="gymnasium%20%28ancient%20Greece%29">Greek gymnasium</a> from the <a href="Hellenistic%20period">Hellenistic period</a> was found in the ruins of Philoteris by the <a href="German%20Archaeological%20Institute">German Archaeological Institute</a> (DAI). The structure had a <a href="hall">hall</a> for meetings, a <a href="cafeteria">dining hall</a>, <a href="courtyard">courtyard</a>, <a href="race%20track">race track</a>, and <a href="garden">garden</a>s in what was "an ideal layout for a center of Greek learning." Contemporaneously, the gymnasium was only for males under 31; "women, slaves, freedmen, tradesmen, male prostitutes, drunkards and madmen were excluded." One of DAI's archaeological scholars in Egypt, Professor <a href="Cornelia%20R%C3%B6mer">Cornelia Römer</a>, told <a href="Deutsche%20Welle">Deutsche Welle</a> that "the gymnasium of [Philoteris] clearly shows the impact of Greek life in Egypt, not only in <a href="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, but also in the countryside".
In the 21st century, the <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>ian settlement of <a href="Madinat%20Watfa">Madinat Watfa</a> was on the site of Philoteris' ruins, southwest of <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>.
